quotes.text: My three co-founders were deeply technical, but I would look at other things about founders. All these little social cues.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: Highlights a complementary evaluation framework for founders that goes beyond technical ability by focusing on interpersonal signals.

quotes.text: I would look at, do the co-founders get along? Are these people committed? And if a founder would get defensive, that was always a bad sign.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: Gives a practical checklist of founder dynamics to assess, including a specific red flag (defensiveness).

quotes.text: But I remember specifically Joe brought out the cereal boxes, the Obama O's and Cap'n McCain's, and I just thought, oh my God, they're going to work hard to do whatever they can to make this company succeed.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: A concrete example of using scrappy behavior as evidence of founder hustle and determination.

quotes.text: Do you sort of need that desperation. You have to burn the boat.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: A memorable mental model suggesting commitment and urgency can be a necessary ingredient for startup success.

quotes.topic_title: Being erased and credit for founding YC
quotes.text: But it is what it is. It's the external views, and it doesn't matter to me.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: A practical mindset for founders/operators: don’t let external narratives dictate your self-worth or focus.

quotes.topic_title: Being erased and credit for founding YC
quotes.text: People within YC know what I've done, the Y Combinator alumni know what I've done, my friends and family and people I respect in the Silicon Valley community know what I've done, most of them do. So that's fine.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: A framework for validation: prioritize credibility with the people who actually have context and matter to your work.

quotes.topic_title: Being erased and credit for founding YC
quotes.text: But it is true, I've often been sort of erased, and in some cases it's annoying because it's a lot of people who have a certain narrative about Y Combinator that don't want me to exist, I'm maybe making that up a little bit, or the people that don't want me to be part of the narrative are the ones that think that Y Combinator, it's run by white men, only invests in white men.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: Highlights how omission can be an intentional narrative tactic—useful for practitioners to recognize when stories are being shaped by incentives.

quotes.topic_title: Being erased and credit for founding YC
quotes.text: And gosh, if there was a woman on the founding team making choices of who to fund, that would undermine their narrative. So I think sometimes that's what happens too.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: A counterintuitive observation: facts may be ignored not due to lack of evidence, but because they weaken a preferred storyline.

quotes.text: Enterpret unifies all of your customer interactions, from Gong calls to Zendesk tickets, to Twitter threads, to app store reviews, and makes it available for your product team.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Enterpret)
quotes.context: A practical approach to centralizing fragmented customer feedback sources into one system for product decision-making.

quotes.text: What makes Enterpret special is its ability to build customer-specific adaptive AI models that provide the most granular and accurate categorization of all your customer feedback, and also connect customer feedback to revenue impact, to help product leaders confidently prioritize things that will actually move the needle for your business.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Enterpret)
quotes.context: Introduces a prioritization methodology that ties qualitative feedback directly to revenue impact to guide roadmap decisions.

quotes.text: Getting to market fast is a top priority for product teams.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Anvil)
quotes.context: A succinct reminder of a core product execution principle that can guide tradeoffs and tooling choices.

quotes.text: And the last thing that you or your developers want is to build document workflows from scratch; it's time-consuming, expensive and distracts from core work.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Anvil)
quotes.context: Actionable build-vs-buy guidance: avoid reinventing non-differentiated infrastructure that slows delivery.

quotes.text: For your users, paperwork often starts with an AI-powered web form styled and embedded in your application.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Anvil)
quotes.context: A concrete implementation pattern for modern document workflows: embedded intake forms as the front door.

quotes.text: When we'd have these 10-minute interviews, I would look at, do the co-founders get along? Are these people committed? Do they really know about their product? Do they care? Are they going to quit their job? Or are they telling us that they are going to quit their job, but really aren't? All these little social cues that I'd try to pick up on.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: A practical checklist of founder signals to evaluate quickly, beyond product/tech quality.

quotes.text: And in a lot of cases, red flags about them that I'd add to the decision-making process.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: Highlights a methodology: systematically incorporating interpersonal “red flags” into selection decisions.

quotes.text: But I would be just watching them and sort of trying to observe as much as I could, not understanding sometimes even the technology that they were talking about. I let my co-founders do that.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: Counterintuitive division of labor: non-technical evaluators can contribute by focusing on human dynamics and behavior.

quotes.text: Or sometimes I'd say, "Guys, I'm a little nervous. Did you see how that founder interrupted the other founder and wouldn't let the other founder talk?" Because my three co-founders sometimes wouldn't notice this.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: Concrete example of a subtle co-founder dynamic that can predict team dysfunction and is easy to miss in technical deep-dives.

quotes.text: And then he'd say, "Fund them." And I'd say, "Whoa, whoa, whoa, Paul, you can't just fund this because you love the idea. Let's take a step back and let's look. Like these two founders are working at Google and they don't say they're going to quit. That's not good."
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: A decision-making guardrail: don’t let excitement about an idea override commitment signals like willingness to quit a job.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding assholes and building YC culture
quotes.text: But I did consciously, especially early on, less so later on, early on, I did sometimes tend to say, "I really think this person's an asshole, I do not want to fund them."
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: A clear, values-based screening rule: explicitly factor interpersonal behavior into high-stakes selection decisions, especially when culture is still forming.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding assholes and building YC culture
quotes.text: And very early on when we were just funding 10, 20, 30 startups a batch, sometimes I have been known to say, "I don't know if I can have dinner with them every week."
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: A practical heuristic for evaluating founder fit: imagine recurring close contact and use that as a filter for long-term working relationships.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding assholes and building YC culture
quotes.text: But life's too short, and I wanted to be able to work with these founders.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: A memorable principle that prioritizes sustainable collaboration over tolerating toxic behavior for potential upside.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding assholes and building YC culture
quotes.text: And as it turns out, it was sort of important early on in weeding out explicit assholes because that was the basis of our Y Combinator community, which is now thousands of founders.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: Counterintuitive long-term payoff: early selection against toxic personalities compounds into a scalable, supportive network effect.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding assholes and building YC culture
quotes.text: So if you ask a question on Bookface, on our forum for founders, someone is going to be there to help you.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: A concrete example of how culture manifests operationally: build systems where help-seeking reliably triggers peer support.

quotes.text: In the application, I'd look for just weird things, like was there a huge gap in the equity allocation? Did one founder have 99% and one founder have 1%? That's weird. I'd want to dig in on that. That doesn't feel right.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: A concrete application-screening heuristic: extreme equity splits are a red flag worth investigating.

quotes.text: What are their current shareholders? Is like 90% of their company already owned by someone else? There all these weird things that we like to just flag. And we wouldn't necessarily not fund someone because of them, but it's just more data.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: A practical methodology: treat red flags as signals to investigate, not automatic disqualifiers.

quotes.text: if a founder would get defensive, that was always a bad sign, always a bad sign.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: An interview tell that predicts poor outcomes: defensiveness under questioning.

quotes.text: The best founders would say, "Gosh, I have thought about it and here's what I figured out." Or, they just have this almost a tennis match and a conversation rather than closing up and feeling like, oh, this person's interrogating me.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: A memorable model for strong founder behavior: collaborative back-and-forth instead of shutting down.

quotes.text: one founder, once we asked a question and one person started to respond and the other founder put his arm in front of him and said, "I'll answer that question." And it was just so weird that he wouldn't let his co-founder speak.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: A vivid example of a co-founder control dynamic that signals unhealthy team relationships.

quotes.text: First of all, being defensive is really bad, if you're a startup founder, because you're always going to get people who question you.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: Highlights defensiveness as a practical failure mode because skepticism is constant for founders.

quotes.text: And it's your job to educate them, if it's a new area, you're doing something presumably pretty new, you're always going to have people who question it or say, "That product's already out there, why is yours better?" You have to educate them.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: Gives an actionable posture for handling doubt: treat objections as prompts to explain and clarify value.

quotes.text: Also, a lot of times, the first idea isn't bang right on, the right idea, and you have to be open-minded and maybe adjust it in a certain direction.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: Encodes a core startup methodology: expect initial ideas to be wrong and iterate based on learning.

quotes.text: You have to be open-minded to see what direction really is what your users want.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: Emphasizes user-driven adaptation as the key reason open-mindedness predicts founder success.

quotes.text: So many founders think, oh, I can't learn from anyone. But the best founders are always listening and having spirited debates about things.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: Contrasts common founder behavior with a high-performing pattern: active listening and debate as a learning engine.

quotes.topic_title: Airbnb interview: hustlers and founder bet
quotes.text: I loved when I'd find someone sort of showcase that they'd make something happen no matter what; they're scrappy, they're hustlers.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: A clear hiring/investing heuristic: prioritize demonstrated scrappiness and follow-through over polish.

quotes.topic_title: Airbnb interview: hustlers and founder bet
quotes.text: And so we were only funding startups that we felt had really scrappy founders and could be cockroaches, meaning could live off of very little amounts of money, or could charge customers and make money.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: A memorable mental model (“cockroaches”) for resilience: survive on little or get to revenue fast, especially in downturns.

quotes.topic_title: Airbnb interview: hustlers and founder bet
quotes.text: In fact, it's a famous part of the story, we hated their idea and Paul tried to get Brian and Joe and Nate to change it. So we didn't even like the idea.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: Counterintuitive founder-market bet: back exceptional founders even when the initial idea seems bad and may need to change.

quotes.topic_title: Airbnb interview: hustlers and founder bet
quotes.text: They were saying that they went to some Costco or something and bought off-brand Cheerios and off-brand Cap'n Crunch's, took them out of the box, put them in this new box, glue-gunned it shut.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: A concrete example of scrappy execution and willingness to do unglamorous work to create momentum.

quotes.topic_title: Airbnb interview: hustlers and founder bet
quotes.text: We've got to fund these guys. I don't know about the idea. Maybe they'll change their idea, who knows? But they seem really great.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: A practical decision rule: when the team is outstanding, invest even amid uncertainty about the current product direction.

quotes.topic_title: More founder-bet stories: GOAT and others
quotes.text: These founders are so good. I'm totally convinced. What they're working on might not work, but I feel like it's so worth the bet based on these founders.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: A clear investor/operator heuristic: place the bet on exceptional founders even when the initial idea is uncertain.

quotes.topic_title: More founder-bet stories: GOAT and others
quotes.text: You just feel like they know what they're talking about, they thought about the problem.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: A practical interview signal to look for: deep understanding and evidence of real problem thinking.

quotes.topic_title: More founder-bet stories: GOAT and others
quotes.text: They're not solving this problem because it's sort of the problem du jour or fun and exciting.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: A counter-signal for founder selection: avoid “trend-chasing” motivation in favor of authentic problem pull.

quotes.topic_title: More founder-bet stories: GOAT and others
quotes.text: Some are very unsexy problems like when Parker Conrad applied with Zenefits, unsexy HR stuff, benefits stuff. But he knew how broken it was and was trying to fix it.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: Concrete example showing that domain insight in “boring” markets can be a strong predictor of success.

quotes.topic_title: More founder-bet stories: GOAT and others
quotes.text: And I, for some reason, just thought, these are hustlers. These guys are scrappy. They're going to make this succeed. And they didn't make that company succeed, but they pivoted and made GOAT succeed and it's doing really, really well.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: Illustrates a founder-quality lens (scrappy hustlers) and the practical value of backing teams that can pivot to a winning idea.

quotes.text: I hate using the word charisma because there are a lot of charismatic people who are full of baloney, and are just doing a startup because it's a cool thing to do now. And I wouldn't want anyone to get fooled by charisma. There has to be some substance behind that charisma.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: A cautionary heuristic: treat charisma as a weak signal unless it’s backed by real substance and motivation.

quotes.text: I've certainly talked to my fair share of totally uncharismatic people, but sometimes they're really good founders too. If they know what they're doing and care about the user and are fixing a problem that they have a deep connection to.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: Reframes founder evaluation toward user empathy and problem connection over presentation skills.

quotes.text: Earnestness is one of the most important because earnest, sort of to me, is bucketed with authenticity. And to be a successful startup founder, you have to care so much about the problem you're trying to solve, the users you're serving and being earnest about it is so key to success.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: Introduces “earnestness/authenticity” as a core selection criterion and success driver for founders.

quotes.text: I think it means being sort of humble about... And if you get asked a question in the interview and you don't know the answer, they say, "I don't know the answer to that. I'd have to think about it." Or, "I don't know the answer. I've given it some thought and here's what I have come up with." And they're just honest about things, and they're not trying to do the whole smoke and mirrors thing, which we've definitely gotten people like that, that avoid the question or are doing it for the wrong reasons.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: Gives a concrete, actionable behavioral test for earnestness: honest uncertainty beats evasive confidence.

quotes.text: I remember there was one group that were 45-year-old men and they were building an app for teenagers in fashion. And I remember just thinking, we were asking them, "Why have you chosen teenagers in fashion?" And it was so clear that they thought they could make easy money, and it wasn't because they cared about fashion. It wasn't because, "Oh, I have a daughter who's really into fashion and I've seen this need." It was just like, they made up the idea. And that is not earnest, that is not authentic to me.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: A vivid example of how lack of authentic connection to the user/problem reveals “made up” startup ideas.

quotes.topic_title: Confidence and commitment: quitting and co-founder fit
quotes.text: confidence means you can say, "I've thought about that and I don't know the answer." That's confidence. And they'll say, "But here's what I do to try to figure it out. Here are my plans to address that."
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: Defines a practical test for real confidence: admitting uncertainty while showing a concrete plan to resolve it.

quotes.topic_title: Confidence and commitment: quitting and co-founder fit
quotes.text: especially when it comes to fundraising, you cannot go into an investor meeting lacking confidence. You can come into YC's interview lacking confidence, but we will then help you in the next three months to gain more confidence.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: Highlights a key difference between fundraising and accelerator selection: confidence is mandatory for investors but coachable in YC.

quotes.topic_title: Confidence and commitment: quitting and co-founder fit
quotes.text: but at some point you have to commit, you have to burn the boat, because we found that founders who were still getting a paycheck and health insurance, once the going got tough, they did not quit their job.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: Gives an actionable commitment threshold: keeping a safe job undermines follow-through when the startup gets hard.

quotes.topic_title: Confidence and commitment: quitting and co-founder fit
quotes.text: I spent a lot of my time at Y Combinator when I was there all the time, full time, mediating co-founder disputes. And so many startups died or had near-death experiences because the co-founders didn't get along or broke up.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: Emphasizes co-founder relationship risk as a primary startup failure mode based on her firsthand YC experience.

quotes.topic_title: Confidence and commitment: quitting and co-founder fit
quotes.text: It's really scary when two founders get together just to start the startup and don't have any history. Massive red flag.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: Provides a clear heuristic for co-founder fit: lack of prior relationship is a major warning sign.

quotes.text: When it comes to ensuring your company has top-notch security practices, things get complicated fast.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights the practical reality that security/compliance complexity escalates quickly, motivating proactive systems and tooling.

quotes.text: Now, you can assess risk, secure the trust of your customers and automate compliance for SOC 2, ISO 27001, HIPAA and more with a single platform, Vanta.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Actionable suggestion to consolidate risk, trust, and compliance workflows into one platform rather than managing them piecemeal.

quotes.text: Vanta's market-leading trust management platform helps you continuously monitor compliance alongside reporting and tracking risk.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Introduces a methodology of continuous compliance monitoring paired with reporting and risk tracking (not point-in-time audits).

quotes.text: Plus, you can save hours by completing security questionnaires with Vanta AI.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Concrete efficiency claim practitioners can apply: use AI to reduce time spent on repetitive security questionnaires.

quotes.text: Join thousands of global companies that use Vanta to automate evidence collection, unify risk management, and streamline security reviews.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Provides a specific adoption data point (“thousands”) and a clear three-part operational model: automate evidence, unify risk, streamline reviews.

quotes.text: I cannot help myself noticing weird things, just dumb things, like if Paul had on a yellow T-shirt and then an hour later came in with a blue T-shirt, I'd be like, "Why do you have a blue T-shirt on?" I have to understand what happened in that hour where that T-shirt is different.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: A concrete example of her “anomaly detection” approach—spot small changes and investigate the hidden story behind them.

quotes.text: I spent hours and hours on the phone with people, with my girlfriends, dissecting situations, and then all through high school, and college, I mean the amount of time we wasted discussing social matters with people, and boys, and things like that.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: Highlights deliberate (if informal) practice: repeated post-mortems of social situations as a way to build people-reading skill.

quotes.text: And I definitely notice and having an aversion to phony people. I always have. I've never been one to fall for someone who's super phony and tried to have them as a friend or anything. I just can tell, and ugh, I hate it.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: A practical filter for relationships and hiring: treat “phoniness detection” as a key signal and avoid getting pulled in by performative behavior.

quotes.text: But what I really want to know about you is, on the release that you sent, or on the instructions for this podcast, you said, "There might be some edge cases where your podcast isn't good enough to go out. We just want to warn you." And all I could think of is, what prompted that? There has to be a story of what prompted that.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: Demonstrates a method for inferring motives: notice unusual wording/policies and assume there’s a specific incident behind them—then ask for the story.

quotes.text: Yes, I did add that. There's a story, basically, it was just an episode that wasn't amazing and we didn't have that caveat in the prep beforehand, and it felt bad to tell the person.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Validates the “policy implies incident” heuristic with a specific example of how edge-case disclaimers often come from a painful prior experience.

quotes.topic_title: Validating instincts, being fooled, and YC tooling
quotes.text: Sometimes I'll have a feeling about someone, maybe we fund them, maybe we don't. I'd sort of like to know what happens a few years later. I like to follow up.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: A practical method for calibrating intuition over time: track outcomes years later to validate (or falsify) your gut calls.

quotes.topic_title: Validating instincts, being fooled, and YC tooling
quotes.text: So I do try to sort of follow up with some of the really strong gut instincts that I had, to see if I was right.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: Reinforces a repeatable feedback loop for improving judgment: revisit your strongest instincts and check accuracy.

quotes.topic_title: Validating instincts, being fooled, and YC tooling
quotes.text: But then the 10 minutes is kind of as long as you need, in most cases. Because we found when they were longer, like 20 minutes, you'd know in 10 minutes and be twiddling your thumbs trying to get through the interview for the next 10 minutes. So we kept them short so we could interview more people.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: A counterintuitive process insight: shorter interviews can be sufficient and increase throughput without sacrificing decision quality.

quotes.topic_title: Validating instincts, being fooled, and YC tooling
quotes.text: No, it's all just stuff in application that automatically flags certain things. I actually don't remember all of them, but it's just, all it is, is a, "Please pay attention to this, reader of the application." It's not, "This disqualifies anyone." It's, "Just please pay attention."
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: A lightweight tooling model: use automated flags to focus reviewer attention on risk factors without turning them into hard disqualifiers.

quotes.topic_title: Validating instincts, being fooled, and YC tooling
quotes.text: Ilya Lichtenstein of MixRank. Do you know the guy that stole billions of dollars in Bitcoin from a crypto wallet? Do you not know this crazy, crazy story?
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: A vivid example of being fooled even with strong social radar, highlighting the limits of short interactions and the need for humility in evaluation.

quotes.topic_title: How to develop a "social radar" checklist
quotes.text: I really think that our advantage was that my three co-founders were deeply technical people.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: Highlights a counterintuitive edge in early-stage investing: technical depth (not just people-reading) can materially improve founder evaluation.

quotes.topic_title: How to develop a "social radar" checklist
quotes.text: I mean, I think just try to pay attention to subtle cues.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: A simple, actionable directive that frames “social radar” as an attention practice rather than a set of tricks.

quotes.topic_title: How to develop a "social radar" checklist
quotes.text: Maybe have your own little checklist that you think about.
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: Introduces a lightweight mental model—use a checklist—to make qualitative judgments more consistent and repeatable.

quotes.topic_title: How to develop a "social radar" checklist
quotes.text: Do they understand their product well? Are they defensive?
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: Provides concrete evaluation criteria that practitioners can directly apply in founder or team assessments.

quotes.topic_title: How to develop a "social radar" checklist
quotes.text: "How did you two meet? Have you ever worked together before? How's it going?"
quotes.speaker: Jessica Livingston
quotes.context: Gives specific, high-signal questions to uncover co-founder history and relationship dynamics.
